moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. c4 dxc4 3. Na3 c5 4. Nxc4 Nc6 5. b3 Bf5 6. Bb2 Nf6
comment:
'Black develops his pieces sensibly
but with no specific aims in view' - Ray Keene commenting on Andersson -
Radulov, Nice 1974. In that game Black played b6 and Bb7 but the salient
feature is the same. White's control of e5. Black's best plan involves f6 and
e5, as Alex Nisbet demonstrated to me in the SCCA Championship 1997-98.

moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. c4 dxc4 3. Na3 c5 4. Nxc4 Nc6 5. b3 Bf5 6. Bb2 Nf6 7. Rc1 e6 8. g3 Be7 9. Bg2 Qc7 10. O-O O-O 11. d3 Rad8
comment:
The Black Rooks surely
belong on c8 and d8, and his next move invites occupation of e5 with tempo.

moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. c4 dxc4 3. Na3 c5 4. Nxc4 Nc6 5. b3 Bf5 6. Bb2 Nf6 7. Rc1 e6 8. g3 Be7 9. Bg2 Qc7 10. O-O O-O 11. d3 Rad8 12. Rc2 Rd7 13. Qa1
comment:
# The authentic Reti formation - see for example the
classic Reti - Rubinstein, Karlsbad 1923. But my favourite example, indeed my
all time favourite game is Larsen - Geller, Copenhagen 1960, culminating in
the wonderful move Qa1-h8!

moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. c4 dxc4 3. Na3 c5 4. Nxc4 Nc6 5. b3 Bf5 6. Bb2 Nf6 7. Rc1 e6 8. g3 Be7 9. Bg2 Qc7 10. O-O O-O 11. d3 Rad8 12. Rc2 Rd7 13. Qa1 Rc8 14. Nce5 Nb4 15. Rcc1 Rd6
comment: Presumably Black intended to play this Rook to a6, but see note at move 19.

moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. c4 dxc4 3. Na3 c5 4. Nxc4 Nc6 5. b3 Bf5 6. Bb2 Nf6 7. Rc1 e6 8. g3 Be7 9. Bg2 Qc7 10. O-O O-O 11. d3 Rad8 12. Rc2 Rd7 13. Qa1 Rc8 14. Nce5 Nb4 15. Rcc1 Rd6 16. e4 Bg4 17. d4
comment:
# 'This position would gladen the heart of Reti himself.
For his subtle opening has, ultimately, the same object as all the others -
the domination of the centre'. Peter Clarke on Tal - Botvinnik, 1960 match
game 11. Yes, tal was White!

moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. c4 dxc4 3. Na3 c5 4. Nxc4 Nc6 5. b3 Bf5 6. Bb2 Nf6 7. Rc1 e6 8. g3 Be7 9. Bg2 Qc7 10. O-O O-O 11. d3 Rad8 12. Rc2 Rd7 13. Qa1 Rc8 14. Nce5 Nb4 15. Rcc1 Rd6 16. e4 Bg4 17. d4 Bxf3 18. Bxf3 Qb8 19. dxc5 Rdd8 20. Bd4 Nc6
comment: This is equivelent to resignation, but 20...Nxa2 21.Rc4 would be even worse.

Be5 Bd6 32. Bxd6 Qxd6 33. e5 Qd3
comment: Attacking c4, f3 and b1, but after
